name: Canonical Explanation Corpus

corpus.canonicalExplanation: Request attempts to grant or enable access without requiring authentication, login, or credential verification. This bypasses the fundamental identity verification that protects system resources.
Request attempts to acquire elevated privileges (admin, root, superuser) without proper authorization. This would grant unrestricted access beyond the user's legitimate permissions.
Request attempts to export, transfer, or transmit bulk data to external destinations. This could result in unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information outside organizational boundaries.
Request attempts to create permanent, irrevocable, or non-expiring access. This prevents proper session management and could allow continued access even after credentials should be invalidated.
Request attempts to access, view, or modify resources belonging to other users. This violates the principle of least privilege and user data isolation.
Request attempts to operate without logging, tracking, or audit trail. This prevents accountability and forensic analysis of potentially malicious actions.
Request attempts to bypass sandbox restrictions, remove rate limits, or escape isolation boundaries. This could allow unrestricted resource consumption or access to protected system areas.

The proposed action would grant a single actor control over all system resources, violating the principle of distributed authority. No entity should have unchecked power over the entire resource space.
The proposed action would allow an actor to elevate their own privilege level without external authorization. Privilege changes require explicit approval from a higher authority.
The proposed action would allow a single actor to accumulate authority by impersonating or controlling multiple identities. This concentrates power in violation of separation principles.
The proposed action would allow an actor confined within a security boundary to access or control resources outside that boundary. Isolation boundaries must be respected.
The proposed action would allow access from one security scope to resources in a different scope without explicit authorization. Scope boundaries enforce data isolation.
The proposed action would transfer data from one trust domain to another without permitted flow. Domain boundaries prevent unauthorized information disclosure.
The proposed action would create an authority relationship with infinite duration that cannot be revoked. All authorities must be time-bounded and revocable.
